questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of diabetes presents with cataracts. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation in this condition?
After the uneventful placement of an intraocular lens in a young patient during cataract surgery, what further steps should be taken?

options.label: C
options.text: Relaced when secondary cataract develops Replaced when presbyopia develops

questions.text: What is the average degree of hypermetropia in a newborn?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - +2.5 D

Type of Hypermetropia

Cause

Axial Hypermetropia

Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form.

Curvatural Hypermetropia

Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Index Hypermetropia

Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics.

Positional Hypermetropia

Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens.

Aphakia

Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia.

Consecutive Hypermetropia

Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery.

questions.text: What could be the most probable cause for the progressive vision loss in both eyes of a 25-year-old male who has been undergoing low-dose oral steroid therapy for the past decade?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - C

questions.text: True statement regarding KF ring: Seen in all patient with neurological involvement Is pathognomonic for Wilson’s disease Resolves with desferroxamine Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement Seen in superior and inferior descemets membrane
What is the formula utilized to calculate the power of the lens during cataract surgery for a patient who has previously undergone LASIK for myopia?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Haigis L

SRK (Option A and B)

Hoffer Q (Option C)

Holladay I

  • P= A-2.5L-0.9K
    (L= axial length)
    (K= constant)
  • Normal axial length (24 mm)
  • Short axial length (<22mm)
  • Long axial length ( >24.5 mm)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?

options.label: D
options.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Hard exudate, diabetes mellitus

Feature

Soft Exudates (Cotton-Wool Spots)

Hard Exudates

Appearance
  • Cloud-like, small, ill-defined, whitish patches
  • Bright yellow, well-defined lipid deposits

Formation Mechanism
  • Caused by ischemia and axonal swelling; blockage of axoplasmic flow
  • Formed by leakage of fluid rich in proteins and lipids

Location
  • Superficial retinal layers, often seen around the optic nerve
  • Seen around leaking microaneurysms, especially in the macula

Common Shape
  • Indistinct and variable; may change shape quickly
  • Radial, star-shaped figure in the macula (macular fan/star)

Main Causes
  • Hypertensive retinopathy (Most common cause)
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Lupus erythematosus (LE)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • Retinopathy associated with AIDS
  • Diabetic retinopathy (Most common cause) (Option B)
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Coats' disease
  • Circinate retinopathy

Image

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: [
Match the given images to their descriptions: 1. A. Posterior subcapsular cataract 2. B. Sunflower cataract 3. C. Morgagnian cataract 4. D. Snowflake cataract
questions.explanation:
1.

B) Sunflower cataract:

  • Deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens.
  • Cause: Wilson's disease

 

2.

C) Morgagnian cataract:

  • Seen in hypermature senile cataract
  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

3.

D) Snowflake cataract:

  • Also known as snowburst cataract
  • Cause: Diabetes mellitus

 

4.

A) Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • Opacity below the capsule in the central part of the posterior cortex.
  • Causes:
    • Complicated cataract
    • Blunt trauma
    • Myotonic dystrophy (Christmas tree cataract)
    • Glactosemia (Oil droplet cataract)
    • Drugs: Steroid, chloroquine, busulfan

 

Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

 
  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: What substance is responsible for the development of a diabetic cataract in a 68-year-old female patient, which has been present for 3 months?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - S

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.correct_answer: D. Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL
questions.explanation:
Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining for the anterior capsule of lens ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Trypan Blue

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon commonly performed?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)

questions.text: Which lens is utilized in direct gonioscopy?
Which is the type of cataract seen following a blunt trauma?
Oil drop cataract is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Galactosemia

Inborn error of galactose metabolism

Enzyme deficiency

  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT)
  • Galactokinase (GK)

Type of cataract

  • Bilateral
  • “Oil droplet” (Option A)
  • Central lens

Features

  • May be reversed
  • May be prevented if milk and milk products are eliminated at an early stage

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient develops endophthalmitis with vision limited to hand movements. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics (Option A):
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics (Option D)
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours (Option B) or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

questions.text: Which of the following cataracts is seen in blunt trauma?
A 2-month-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the following presentation. What is the ideal management?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - O

questions.text: A patient presents with decreased vision three years after surgery and exhibits this condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Posterior capsular opacification (PCO)

questions.text: What is Anisometropia?

options.label: B
options.text: Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes

options.label: C
options.text: Difference in the axial length of the eyeball

options.label: D
options.text: Difference in the size of the eyeball

questions.correct_answer: B. Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance . His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: Rosette cataract is seen after?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Blunt trau

questions.explanation: Correct Option A -Homocystinu

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 55-year-old male patient who visited the OPD with complaints of experiencing glare while driving at night, despite having cataract surgery a year ago? The patient's best corrected visual acuity is 6/12 in the right eye and 6/9 in the left eye, with no improvement observed when using a pinhole.
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Posterior capsu
